Fig. 1 The acetylene conversion (a) and selectivity to VCM (b) over the Au-N4/AC, Au-P1/AC, and Au-O1/AC catalysts. Reaction conditions: temperature = 180 °C, GHSV(C2H2) = 1200 h−1, and V HCl /V C2H2 = 1.15. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 UV–vis adsorption spectra of the solutions. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 k3-weighted Fourier transform spectra of Au-based catalysts (No phase correction) (a) and XANES spectra at the Au L3 edge (b). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TPR profiles of the unreacted Au-based catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XRD patterns of the unreacted (a) and reacted (b) Au-based catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 TEM images of the unreacted (left panel) and reacted (right panel) catalysts: AC (a, b), Au/AC (c, d), Au-N4/AC (e, f), Au-P1/AC (g, h), and Au-O1/AC (i, j); about 150 particles were measured for the catalysts to analyze the particle size distribution. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 HAADF-STEM images of the unreacted catalysts: Au/AC (a), Au-N4/AC (b), and Au-P1/AC (c). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 C2H2-TPD (a) and HCl-TPD (b) profiles of the unreacted Au catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 TG/DTG curves of the unreacted and reacted Au-P1/AC catalysts. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Energy profiles of Au2Cl6-catalyzed acetylene hydrochlorination reaction pathway. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Energy profiles of Au-P1-catalyzed acetylene hydrochlorination reaction pathway. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Energy profiles of Au-N4-catalyzed acetylene hydrochlorination reaction pathway. Graphical abstract In line with the fulfillment of international Minamata Convention and the urgent need for developing non-mercury catalysts, Au-L x /AC catalysts were synthesized and evaluated for the hydrochlorination of acetylene. The results showed that the interaction between ligands and Au species contributed to the enhanced catalytic activity with important and different roles of each ligand. Depending on the high electronegativity of heteroatoms, all the prepared catalysts had effectively improved their adsorption and activation capacity of hydrogen chloride. Specifically, the N-containing ligands in catalysts increased the dispersion of Au species and an enhanced adsorption of acetylene was observed. Whilst, the coordination of P-containing ligands with Au can increase the relative content of active Aun+ species and the O-containing ligands rather decreased the adsorption of acetylene. Furthermore, all the prepared Au-L x /AC catalysts showed good stabilities based on the inhibition of the agglomeration of Au components or of coking deposition. Keywords Au complex catalyst Heteroatom-containing ligand Acetylene hydrochlorination Improved performance 1 Introduction Polyvinyl chloride synthesized via polymerization of the vinyl chloride monomer (VCM) is one of the five general resin materials that have the highest output and usage in the world. Polyvinyl chloride is widely available for daily necessities and the construction industry because of its low price and good mechanical properties [1]. A long-established industrial process in coal-rich regions is acetylene hydrochlorination, which is run over volatile and highly toxic mercury catalysts, causing serious harm to both environment and human beings [2]. In accordance with the Minamata Convention and with sustainable development of the chlor-alkali industry, an environmentally feasible alternative catalyst is imperative [3]. On this basis, several metal substitutes, including Au [4,5], Pt [6], Pd [7], Ru [8], Cu [9], and Sn [10], have been explored as potential mercury-free catalysts for the catalytic synthesis of VCMs; among these, gold-based catalysts have emerged as the most promising candidates. Despite its extraordinary activity however, monometallic Au catalysts have some insurmountable drawbacks, for instance, (i) the reduction of Aun+ to Au° species [11,12], (ii) the occurrence of coking deposition [3,11] and (iii) the agglomeration of Au species [13]. These drawbacks lead to the rapid deactivation of Au catalysts and thwart its industrial application. Therefore, researchers have made great efforts to address these shortcomings through making Au-based bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts to improve catalytic activity and stability in terms of high dispersion, valence stabilization of the Au species, and their synergistic effect between additives (Cu [14], La [15], Co [16], Bi [17], Ni [18], Cs [19], Sn [20], Y [21], Li [22], Sr [23], Co-Cu [24], Cs-In [25], et al) [3]. On the other side, by decorating surface functional groups on supports, especially the carbon support were well known to act synergistically as the active sites within the Au-based catalysts in acetylene hydrochlorination [26]. Extensive studies on support modification were investigated, leading to adjusting the adsorption, electron conduction, and other physicochemical properties of the host through (i) in situ or post-treated doping modification of nonmetallic elements such as N [27], P [28], O [29], S [30], and B [31], and (ii) synthesizing supports with peculiar structures such as activated carbon fibers [32] and thermally activated carbons [33]. Hutchings et al. [34] performed an in situ XAFS study of the Au/C catalyst and found that the high performance of the catalysts was related to the Au(I)/Au(III) ratio. Au(I)-Au(III) redox couple was tuned by the pretreatments of the catalysts using several solvents, i.e. aqua regia, nitric acid, and DI water, etc., implying the importance of the ligand effect on the catalytic behaviors. Thanks to this ligand effect, the Aun+ species become more stable in their high-valence state. In fact, investigations on the interaction between Aun+ and ligands (or ionic liquids (ILs)) has been popular all the way. For example, Au-[Bmim]Cl [35], [AuCl2(phen)]Cl [36], AuPPh3Cl [37], Na3Au(S2O3)2 [3], Au-KSCN [38], Au/Cu/TCCA [39], [Prmim]AuCl4 [40], Au-Cu-[Prmim]Cl [41], Au-C3H9SI [42], and AuCl3–thiourea [43] catalysts were largely reported showing enhanced performance in acetylene hydrochlorination, compared to their counterpart (Au/C). The data are listed in Table S1 to compare activities over most of the studied catalysts in literatures. It clearly shows that the investigation on introducing heteroatoms through doping or ligands is large however, there are some controversial issues to reconsider. For example, Luo et al. concludes that the addition of N-containing ligands during catalyst preparation can change energy profiles in reaction pathways and adsorption energies of each reactant and product based on theoretical study [44], whilst Pérez-Ramírez et al. reported that the carbon carrier doped with or without N does not affect its catalytic activity, but it rather determines the deactivation mechanism, including Au particle aggregation and pore blockage [33]. Their different opinions might be attributed to the different methodologies, i.e., theoretical vs. experimental. It can be suggestive for us to expand the scope of heteroatoms in preparing Au-based catalysts and meanwhile to perform the work both theoretically (Density functional theory) and experimentally in order to provide more evidences to support this research field. Accordingly, we have now studied Au-L x /AC (L = N, P, or O) catalysts in regard to a more comprehensive scope by using seven new kinds of N- ligand precursor complexes, five new kinds of O- and P-containing ligand precursor complexes in this work (Detailed information, including activity data are summarized in Table S2) with the aim of gaining further understanding of the influences that different ligands have on their enhanced catalysis in the reaction of acetylene hydrochlorination. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents Coal-based activated carbon (AC, 40–60 mesh) was purchased from Ningxia Huahui Activated Carbon Co., Ltd. Chloroauric acid tetrahydrate (HAuCl4·4H2O, 48.7 % Au content), methylamine hydrochloride (N1), dimethylamine hydrochloride (N2), trimethylamine hydrochloride (N3), tetramethylammonium chloride (N4), trimethylphenylammonium chloride (N5), dodecyltrimethylammonium chloride (N6), trimethylstearylammonium chloride (N7), 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acid (O1), 4-methoxyphenylacetic acid (O2), 4-ethoxyphenylacetic acid (O3), 4-n-butoxyphenylacetic acid (O4), 4-phenoxyphenylacetic acid (O5), dichlorophenylphosphine (P1), di-tert-butylchlorophosphane (P2), tributylphosphine (P3), tetrabutylphosphonium chloride (P4), and tributyltetradecylphosphonium chloride (P5) were provided by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. All of the reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Pristine AC was first treated in 1 mol L−1 HCl solution under reflux at 75 °C for 4 h, and then it was washed with deionized water until the pH was 7. This was done to remove poisons (such as Na and Fe). Then, AC was desiccated at 150 °C for 10 h [45]. The resulting material was labelled as AC and used as a host in the subsequent steps. Supported Au-L x catalysts with 1 wt.% Au content were prepared via wet impregnation, and the procedures are briefly described as follows: First, 41 mg of N1 was dissolved in 6 ml of isopropanol, and 65 mg of HAuCl4·4H2O (Au/L x = 1/4, n/n) was then added to the solution under constant stirring for 30 min. Then, 3 g of AC was added to the solution, which was refluxed at 70 °C for a whole day. Finally, the product was desiccated in an oven at 140 °C for 12 h to yield the Au-N1/AC catalyst. Similarly, the other Au-N x /AC (x = 2–7), Au-P y /AC (y = 1–5), and Au-O z /AC (z = 1–5) catalysts were prepared by replacing the N1 ligand with a certain amount of the other corresponding ligands. The 1Au-nN4/AC, 1Au-nP1/AC and 1Au-nO1/AC catalysts (n = 1–5) were obtained by adjusting the molar ratio of Au to corresponding ligand. After optimization, the optimal 1Au-4N4/AC, 1Au-4P1/AC and 1Au-4O1/AC catalysts were represented by Au-N4/AC, Au-P1/AC and Au-O1/AC, respectively, to concisely indicate the name of the catalysts for further characterization. For comparison, the Au-P1/AC catalyst with Au loading of 0.1 wt.% and Au/AC catalysts with Au loading of 1 wt.% and 0.1 wt.% were also prepared according to the above procedures. 2.3 Catalytic performance test The reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed microreactor (Fig. S1, outer diameter: 24 mm, internal diameter: 8 mm, length: 650 mm). The whole pipeline was first swept with a 20-mL min−1 N2 flow for 30 min to get rid of foreign gases, and then 2 ml of the catalyst was activated by a gas flow of HCl at a rate of 20 ml min−1 for 30 min. Meanwhile, the temperature, which was measured using a thermocouple, was increased to 180 °C at a rate of 5 °C min−1. Finally, a gas flow of HCl (99.9 %) at a rate of 46.0 ml min−1 and a gas flow of acetylene (99.8 %) at a rate of 40.0 ml min−1 were passed through the catalyst bed to initiate the reaction with a gas hourly space velocity of acetylene (GHSV(C2H2)) of 1200 h−1. The acetylene conversion and selectivity to VCMs were analyzed online using gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014C). 2.4 Catalyst characterization UV–vis adsorption spectra of the as-prepared solutions were obtained on a spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher, Evolution 220 UV–vis). Au 4f X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected using an energy spectrometer with an Al-Kα X-ray source (Thermo Fisher, Escalab 250Xi), and the spectra were corrected using C1s (284.6 eV) to quantitatively analyze the element compositions, valence states, and relative contents of Au species. The X-ray absorption spectra were collected on the beamline BL01C1 in NSRRC, and were provided technical support by “Ceshigo Research Service, Agency for XAS and DFT/MD simulation, www.ceshigo.com”. The radiation was monochromatized by a Si (111) double-crystal monochromator. XANES and EXAFS data reduction and analysis were processed by Athena software. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were obtained on an automatic chemical adsorption instrument (Quantachrome, Chembet Pulsar TPR/TPD). A sample (0.1 g) was first treated with high purity helium at 100 °C for 30 min, and then the signal was recorded when the sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a gas flow of 10 % H2/Ar. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on an X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, D8 Advance) with a Cu-Kα radiation source, an operating current of 40 mA, and a voltage of 40 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) images were collected on an electron microscope (JEOL Ltd., JEM 2010) with a working voltage of 200 kV, a minimum lattice resolution of 0.45 eV, and a dot resolution of 0.23 nm. Scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) images were collected on an electron microscope (FEI, Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin), and the images were used to further analyze the element dispersion when the powder was dispersed onto a copper mesh with a 300-mesh size. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) profiles were also obtained on an automatic chemical adsorption instrument (Quantachrome, Chembet Pulsar TPR/TPD). First, 0.1 g of sample was saturated with adsorbed acetylene or HCl at 180 °C and was then treated with high purity helium for 0.5 h at 100 °C. Then, the signal was recorded when the sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under helium flow. After the sample was degassed at 200 °C for 6 h on a specific surface area and aperture analyzer (Micromeritics, ASAP 2020C), the adsorption-desorption isotherms of the catalysts were measured in liquid nitrogen (−196 °C) with relative pressure (P/Po) ranging from 0.01 to 1.0 (68 points) to analyze the texture property of samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using a thermal analyzer (METTLER TOLEDO, TGA2). The weight loss was recorded when the sample was heated from room temperature to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C min-1 under air or nitrogen flow to illustrate the carbon deposition on the reacted catalysts and the leakage of metal or ligands in the fresh catalysts. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) simulation All calculations were conducted with the Gaussian 09 software package. Molecular geometries of all model complexes were fully optimized via DFT calculations using the B3LYP functional. The effective core potential of LANL2DZ basis set was adopted to describe Au, and the 6−31 G (d) basis set was chosen to describe C, O, N, P, H, and Cl. Frequency calculations were conducted at the same level of theory to identify all of the stationary points as transition states or as minima and to provide the thermal correction to free energies at 1 atm and 298.15 K. Intrinsic reaction coordinates (IRC) were also calculated for all transition states. The single-point energy calculations were conducted at the B3LYP level with the SDD for Au, and the 6−311+G (d, p) basis set for all other atoms to get higher accuracy electronic energy. The Gibbs free energy for each species is taken as the sum of the higher accuracy single-point energy in gas phase and the thermal correction to free energies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of the Au-L x /AC catalysts Fig. 1 shows the catalytic performance of Au-L x /AC catalysts for the reaction studied. An almost negligible activity was observed over the bare host AC under a high GHSV(C2H2), and the acetylene conversion was below 3% during the whole reaction. The presence of Au species caused the Au/AC catalyst to have a good initial conversion of 90 %; this decreased to 84 % after 24 h of reaction. In contrast, the complexation of the Au precursor with N-containing ligands improved the activity and stability of the catalysts to different levels (Fig. S2). The optimum activity was achieved on the Au-N4/AC catalyst, with an initial acetylene conversion of 97 % and a relative loss of only 3 % within 24 h of reaction (Fig. S3). Likewise, except for the complexation of the Au precursor with P3, P5, and O5 ligands, the introduction of other P- and O-containing ligands successfully improved the performance of Au catalysts. Among them, the Au-P1/AC and Au-O1/AC catalysts exhibited superior activity with a stable conversion of 97 % (Au-P1/AC) and an initial conversion of 95 % (Au-O1/AC). These values decreased to 96 % and 91 %, respectively, after the test. Moreover, compared with the Au-based catalysts reported in the previous literatures, the optimal Au-P1/AC catalyst also showed good performance (Table S3). Even at 0.1 wt.% Au loading, it still had excellent activity and stability (Fig. S4). Therefore, when considering the higher relative deactivation rate of Au/AC (7 %) compared to Au-L x /AC and the selectivity of > 99 % for VCMs (Fig. 1), it was inferred that the synthesized Au-L x /AC catalysts exhibited outstanding activity and stability for hydrochlorination of acetylene. 3.2 The structure-performance relationship of the catalysts To further illustrate the structure-performance relationship, the representative samples (Au-N4/AC, Au-P1/AC, and Au-O1/AC) exhibited the highest catalytic performance among the three types of catalysts were selected for in-depth characterizations. First, two absorption peaks were diagnosed at 278 nm and 322 nm in the UV–vis adsorption spectrum of the Au solution and corresponded to the d-d transition of the Aun+ species (Fig. 2 ). In contrast, in solutions of Au-N4, Au-P1 and Au-O1, the characteristic peaks of Aun+, especially the peak at 221 nm, were shifted towards lower wavelength, providing the evidence for the Au-L x complexation or interaction [46]. In terms of peak intensity, the peaks of Aun+ in the Au-L x solution had far lower intensity than the superposition intensity of the Au solution and N- or O-containing ligand solution, which was the opposite in the Au-P1 solution. These observations indicate that introducing N- or O-containing ligands reduces the relative content of Aun+ in solution, whereas introducing a P-containing ligand increases the relative content of Aun+ in solution. In addition, XPS characterization can also be used as a measure to further demonstrate the complexation or interaction. As evident from the results, the ligands containing heteroatoms were successfully introduced to the surface of the catalysts (Table S4); the peaks in the Au 4f spectra of the traditional Au/AC catalyst can be decomposed into three types: Au0, Au+, and Au3+ species, which are at 84.2 eV, 85.1 eV, and 86.8 eV, respectively (Table S5 and Fig. S5) [47]. In particular, meticulous analysis of the binding energy of each species in the Au-L x /AC catalysts revealed an apparent shift of the Au species. Those of the metallic Au0 species migrated toward higher values, whereas those of the Aun+ species migrated in the opposite direction with respect to their counterpart Au/AC catalyst. If anything, complexation or interaction may promote electron transfer between heteroatoms and Au species and alter the electron cloud density of active species; this was further confirmed by the positive shift of N, P, and O species in the Au-N4/AC, Au-P1/AC, and Au-O1/AC catalysts, respectively, compared to the N4/AC, P1/AC, and O1/AC samples (Fig. S6). Moreover, as evident from XPS results (Table S5 and Fig. S5), the complexation or interaction with N- or O-containing ligands decreased the relative content of Aun+ species, whereas the complexation with a P-containing ligand, augmented the relative content of Aun+ species in the Au-P1/AC catalyst (47.3 %) compared to that in Au/AC (36.2 %). These observations are in agreement with the UV–vis analysis and with the viewpoint that hard donor ligands with more electronegative atoms (such as halides or N and O atoms) tend to reduce Aun+ species, whereas soft donor ligands that contain P or S atoms are beneficial for stabilizing higher oxidation states (Aun+) [3]. XAS analysis was performed to further reveal the structure property and valence state of Au species in these catalysts [5,34]. The fitting results showed that the coordination number of Au-Cl in Au/AC catalyst is lower than that in AuCl3 standard crystal (Fig. 3 a, Table S6 and Fig. S7). It can be considered that Au precursors were dispersed to form highly dispersed Au species after loading on AC. Meanwhile, the original Au-Cl bond was broken, increasing the unsaturation of Au and enabling the Au catalyst to have better catalytic activity. The coordination number and bond length of Au-Cl bond in Au-N4/AC catalyst are similar to those in Au/AC catalyst, but a weak peak appears in the short distance, which may be related with the coordination of Au-N. However, the relatively low coordination number indicates the partial coordination of Au and N species. After the introduction of P-containing ligands, Au-P/Cl bonds with relatively high coordination numbers appear in Au-P1/AC catalyst, which indicates the interaction between Au and heteroatoms, improving the stability of the catalyst. In addition to Au-Cl bond, Au-Au coordination structures were detected in Au-O1/AC catalyst (Fig. S8). However, the absence of Au-O coordination structure indicates that the gold precursor is difficult to coordinate with the oxygen-containing ligand, and the occurrence of Au-Au bond whose bond length is similar to that of the Au-Au bond in Au foil proves the formation of Au nanoparticles in the catalyst. In addition, as evident from the edge normalized XANES spectrum of Au L3 (Figs. 3b and S9), a very prominent feature on the absorption edge is observed in the XANES region of the Au(III) standard spectrum. The intensity of this peak is reduced in the Au(I) standard and is absent for the Au0 foil [43]. In contrast, the white-line peak intensity of these catalysts are far less than that of Au(III) standard, indicating that the Au 2p→5d transition is inhibited, and there are relatively more Au species with low oxidation state (Au+) in the catalysts. If a distinction is necessary, the decreasing order of white-line peak intensity values in the catalysts (Au-P1/AC > Au/AC > Au-N4/AC > Au-O1/AC) may indicate that compared with Au/AC, Au species in Au-P1/AC catalyst have relatively higher valence states, while Au species in Au-N4/AC and Au-O1/AC catalysts exhibit relatively lower valence states, which is basically consistent with the trend of XPS analysis. TPR profiles were combined to further analyze the valence of Au species. The broad peaks that were located in the range of 350 °C–800 °C for all of the catalysts can be ascribed to the characteristic reduction of functional groups that contain phosphine or oxygen on the surface of host and in the ligands (Fig. 4 ) [12,47]. For the unreacted Au/AC catalyst, there are two weak peaks that correspond to the characteristic reduction of Au3+ and Au+ at 250 °C and 300 °C, respectively [48]; this suggests that a valence state cannot be stabilized because of the presence of functional groups on the surface of the host and the influence of preparation conditions. Similar profiles were identified in the Au-N4/AC, Au-P1/AC, and Au-O1/AC catalysts, and the difference was that the reduction temperature of Aun+ in these catalysts was lower than that of Au/AC. Moreover, considering the area of the reduction peak, the presence of a N-containing ligand slightly reduced the relative content of Aun+. Introducing an O-containing ligands and P-containing ligands greatly reduced and slightly increased the relative content of Aun+, respectively. These results indicate a weaker interaction between Au species and the host and an enhanced interaction between Au species and the heteroatoms in these catalysts, which agrees well with the above results. Apart from the valence state, the other factors that are considered to be the important due to its influence on the activity of catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination are the interaction between the active components and the host, the dispersibility of the active species, and the adsorption of the reactants on the catalyst. There were no visible diffraction peaks of Au except for the amorphous diffraction reflections of carbon in the unreacted Au/AC, Au-N4/AC, and Au-P1/AC catalysts (Fig. 5 ), showing that the size of the Au species is less than 4 nm due to the detection limit of XRD (Table S7) [12]. It is worth noting that there was a reduction and accumulation of Au species in the unreacted Au-O1/AC catalyst, which was verified by the observed crystalline diffraction reflections of Au0 in the XRD pattern; this is consistent with the UV–vis, XPS, XAS, and TPR analysis. TEM and STEM images were recorded to further illuminate the size of particles. On the plus side, introducing heteroatoms produced new active sites on the carbon-based host, and the complexation or interaction of these heteroatoms with Au species might anchor and disperse the pivotal active centers. Although the Au particles in the unreacted Au/AC, Au-N4/AC, and Au-P1/AC catalysts did not have a distinguishable shape (Fig. 6 ), the complexation or interaction of Au precursors with N- or P-containing ligands allowed the atomic-level distribution of Au species, which was further verified by STEM images (Fig. 7 ). The ability of the catalysts to adsorb reactants was directly related to the performance of the supported catalyst. As evident from C2H2-TPD profiles, there was a broad desorption peak in the temperature range of 150 °C–700 °C with an increasing order of Au-P1/AC < AC < Au-O1/AC < Au/AC ≈ Au-N4/AC (Fig. 8 a). In addition, the adsorption amount determined from the peak area increased in the order of AC < Au-O1/AC < Au-P1/AC < Au/AC < Au-N4/AC. It is known that acetylene chemisorption on oxygen defects is less favorable [49]. However, introducing a N-containing ligand increased the relative content of Au° species in the catalyst, and these have a better acetylene adsorption capacity than Aun+ species. In contrast, the coordination of a P-containing ligand with Au precursors increased the relative content of Aun+ and weakened the adsorption of Au species to acetylene [3]. From HCl-TPD results, an explicit desorption of HCl in the temperature range of 150–450 °C was identified for all of the catalysts (Fig. 8b). The interaction or coordination of Au species with N-, P-, or O-containing ligands had a negligible effect on the desorption temperature of HCl from the catalysts, while it clearly affected the adsorption amount of HCl. Surprisingly, the capacity of catalysts to adsorb HCl increased regardless of the relative content of Aun+. It was caused by the introduction of a N-, P- or O-containing ligands, which was different from the reported results in the previous literature suggesting the enhanced adsorption of HCl onto Aun+ compared to N-doped carbon [50]. This suggests that the N, P, or O heteroatoms in these catalysts may be responsible for the adsorption and activation of HCl. Therefore, the HCl and acetylene adsorption sites in the catalysts may be different, and the heteroatom-containing ligands had different catalytic roles. 3.3 The deactivation of the catalysts The inevasible deactivation of the catalysts was explored using a variety of characterization techniques. All of the unreacted and spent catalysts presented a type-I adsorption-desorption isotherm because of the microporous nature of the material (Fig. S10) [42]. The bare host AC displayed the largest specific surface area (S BET) and total pore volume (V P), and these decreased because of the occupation of host pores by the loading of Au or Au-L x species (Table 1 ). To understand the change after reaction, a decrease in S BET and V P of a porous catalyst was ascribed to deposition of coking or collapse of pores during the reaction, as commonly considered, which was observed for each catalyst; the order of ΔS BET (%) increases as follows: Au-P1/AC (6.3 %) < Au-N4/AC (8.7 %) < Au-O1/AC (8.8 %) < Au/AC (21.4 %) < AC (36.2 %). To rationalize the decrease in S BET and V P of the Au-L x /AC catalysts with respect to their counterpart, TGA was performed. A weight loss that resulted from the desorption of moisture was observed below 150 °C for both the fresh and spent catalysts (Fig. 9 ). A rapid weight loss above 500 °C can be attributed to the combustion of the carbon-based host [51]. Therefore, the difference in weight loss between the spent and fresh catalysts in the temperature range of 150 °C–500 °C reflected the amount of coking deposition that results from the polymerization of acetylene or VCMs on the reacted catalyst. Accordingly, the coking deposition of the other catalysts was calculated (Fig. S11 and Table 2 ). Bare AC (6.8 %) and the Au/AC (3.4 %) catalysts apparently suffered from serious coking deposition, which might annihilate active sites on the host’s surface and lower the activity of the catalyst. Introducing ligands reduced the amount of coking deposition during the reaction. Therefore, it can be inferred that the interaction or coordination effectively restrained the formation of byproducts with only 0.6 % ∼ 2.4 % of coking deposition detected on the Au-L x /AC catalysts. In addition, by comparing the TG-DTG results of the fresh catalysts tested under nitrogen atmosphere, it can be seen that a small amount of metal components will be lost in the catalysts at the reaction temperature (180 °C) whether the ligands exist or not (Fig. S12), which may also cause the deactivation of the catalysts. As proven in our previous work [52], using isopropanol as a preparation solvent plays a very important role in maintaining the stability of the valence states of the active components during the reaction. By comparison, there were no significant changes in the relative amount of Aun+ species observed in any of the catalysts during the reaction (Fig. S5 and Table S5). It indicates that the valence change of the Aun+ species was not the dominant reason for the deactivation of these catalysts. Also, introducing ligands did not play a significant role in this regard. In addition, the particles were agglomerated to nanoclusters because of the tendency for small-molecular metallic compounds to coalesce when Au/AC is subjected to reaction; the Au species increase in size from 2.28 nm to 6.05 nm (Figs. 6a-b and 7 a). This is another reason for deactivation of the catalyst. However, although sintering cannot be completely eliminated, the dispersion and anchoring effect by N-containing and P-containing ligands and the steric hindrance of complexes guaranteed high dispersion of Au species. This was proven by TEM images of the spent Au-N4/AC and Au-P1/AC catalysts (Fig. 6c–f) as well as by XRD patterns (Fig. 5 and Table S7). However, the O-containing ligand did not play a positive role in preventing agglomeration of the active species during reaction, which suggests that the O-containing ligand mainly depended on the inhibition of coking deposition to increase the stability of the catalyst. 3.4 Results of DFT calculation For understanding reaction mechanism, a detailed DFT study was performed. The stability of Au-L x under different reaction conditions was first considered (Fig. S13). When there is no additional ligand, the dimer of AuCl3 is more stable than monomer. But when ligand is P1 (L1) or N4 (L3), the complex of the monomer of AuCl3 and ligand is more stable than the dimer of AuCl3. For ligand O1 (L2), the complex of the monomer of AuCl3 and ligand has a similar energy with the dimer of AuCl3. Moreover, according to XAS analysis (Fig. 3), it is difficult for the oxygen-containing ligands to form a stable Au-O coordination structure with the gold precursor. But for comparison, DFT calculation was also carried out for the relatively stable Au-O structure optimized by simulation. As we know, there is a concentration effect when the metal is coordinating with the ligand, and the Au precursor will not fully coordinate with all the ligands added. Therefore, the optimized molecular geometries of the complexes were adopted for subsequent IRC analysis. In the absence of additional ligand, the dimer of AuCl3 first adsorbs one C2H2, which is endergonic by 7.1 kcal/mol. The stable complex A4 can be formed via transition state A-TS1, the energy barrier is 20.7 kcal/mol relative to A1. Subsequently, A4 captures one HCl to generate complex A5, and this step is endergonic by 4.9 kcal/mol. Finally, the product A6 is given via transition state A-TS2, and the overall reaction energy barrier is 37.4 kcal/mol (Fig. 10 ). For the reaction systems with additional ligands, the ligand L1 was first considered. The complex B3 is resting state, and the complex A3 is formed by ligand exchange of L1 and C2H2, which is endergonic by 12.4 kcal/mol. The complex B4 can be generated via transition state B-TS1 with the energy barrier of 19.9 kcal/mol relative to B3. Subsequently, B4 captures one HCl to generate complex B5, together with the releasing of ligand L1, which is endergonic by 24.4 kcal/mol. Finally, the product A6 is formed via transition state B-TS2, and the overall reaction energy barrier is 32.9 kcal/mol (Fig. 11 ). For ligand L2, the reaction pathway is similar with the one including L1. The overall reaction energy barrier is 35.4 kcal/mol (Fig. S14). For ligand L3, although the reaction pathway also involves Au monomer, somewhat differently, there is no ligand exchange of L3 and C2H2 or HCl, and the rate-determining step is the insertion of C2H2 into Au-Cl bond (Fig. 12 ). For four cases including L1, L2, L3, and no ligand, the overall reaction energy barriers are 32.9, 35.4, 35.0, and 37.4 kcal/mol, respectively. The experimental results show that the efficiency of different ligands follows the order: L1 > L3 > L2 > no ligand. This is consistent with the calculation results. 4 Conclusions Carbon-supported Au-L x /AC catalysts were prepared by using a big scope of additive ligand precursor complexes and evaluated for hydrochlorination of acetylene. The results illustrated that different ligands generally exhibit a beneficial interaction with Au species. N-containing ligand increased dispersion of Au species and enhanced the adsorption and activation for both reactants. In addition to improving dispersion of Au components, the coordination of P-containing ligand with Au increased the relative content of the active species and meanwhile increased the adsorption capacity of HCl. However, the O-containing ligand mainly increased the activity of the catalyst by weakening the adsorption of acetylene and enhancing the adsorption and activation of HCl through heteroatoms with high electronegativity. All these conclusions were firmly supported by both experiments and DFT calculations. Compared to their counterpart Au/AC, the Au-N4/AC, Au-P1/AC, and Au-O1/AC catalysts have indeed increased their initial rate at a high GHSV(C2H2) by about 8%, 7%, and 6%, respectively, and effectively inhibited agglomeration of Au components and coking deposition in the reaction process. In short, the ligand effect was well studied in respect to some other new N-, P- and O- precursor complexes in this work and the results are well aligned to the reported Au-L x /AC catalysts in literature. We are confident that what we have found can be useful and supportive for future catalysts research in hydrochlorination of acetylene. coredata.dc:description: In line with the fulfillment of international Minamata Convention and the urgent need for developing non-mercury catalysts, Au-L x /AC catalysts were synthesized and evaluated for the hydrochlorination of acetylene. The results showed that the interaction between ligands and Au species contributed to the enhanced catalytic activity with important and different roles of each ligand. Depending on the high electronegativity of heteroatoms, all the prepared catalysts had effectively improved their adsorption and activation capacity of hydrogen chloride. Specifically, the N-containing ligands in catalysts increased the dispersion of Au species and an enhanced adsorption of acetylene was observed. Whilst, the coordination of P-containing ligands with Au can increase the relative content of active Aun+ species and the O-containing ligands rather decreased the adsorption of acetylene. Furthermore, all the prepared Au-L x /AC catalysts showed good stabilities based on the inhibition of the agglomeration of Au components or of coking deposition.
coredata.dc:title: Effects of N-, P-, or O-containing ligands on gold-based complex catalysts for acetylene hydrochlorination
